substitution.secondary: Check NGP! π/n within 2-3 atoms = 10^3-10^14 boost

basics.back: Substitution Nucleophilic Unimolecular - rate depends only on substrate [RX]
Rate = k[RX] - First order, unimolecular

1) Leaving group departs → carbocation
2) Nucleophile attacks carbocation
Racemization - planar carbocation allows attack from both sides
Tertiary (3°) - most stable carbocation

mechanisms.back: Carbocation intermediate is sp² planar - nucleophile attacks from both faces equally
Polar protic solvents stabilize carbocation and leaving group - FASTER reaction
Higher temp favors SN1 over SN2 - provides energy for bond breaking

ngp.back: Neighboring Group Participation - nearby π/n stabilizes carbocation
Within 2-3 atoms from leaving group for effective orbital overlap
C=C, benzene ring, C≡C triple bond

jee_traps.back: Rate magnitude questions - must know 10^X boost from NGP!
Don't just look at 1°/2°/3° - CHECK for NGP within 2-3 atoms first!

Heat + strong base = E1 favored
Weak base + good solvent = SN1 favored

practice.front: Compare rates: (CH₃)₃CBr vs CH₃CH₂Br in SN1

Which faster in SN1:
CH₃CH(Br)CH=CH₂
vs
CH₃CH₂CH₂Br
practice.back:
CH₃CH(Br)CH=CH₂ MUCH faster
π-NGP from C=C gives 10⁶-10¹⁴× boost!

basics.back: Rate = k[Nu][RX] - Second order, bimolecular
One-step: Nucleophile attacks from backside (180°) while leaving group departs
Inversion (Walden inversion) - 180° backside attack flips configuration
Primary (1°) - least steric hindrance for backside attack
Anti-periplanar - 180° between nucleophile and leaving group

mechanisms.back: Backside attack at 180° → transition state has partial bonds → configuration flips
Steric hindrance - bulky groups block backside attack at 180°
RS⁻ > RO⁻ > NH₂⁻ > F⁻ (larger = better nucleophile in polar aprotic)
I⁻ > Br⁻ > Cl⁻ > F⁻ (weaker base = better leaving group)

practice.back:
CH₃Br >>> (CH₃)₃CBr
1° has no hindrance, 3° impossible for SN2
Polar aprotic (DMSO, acetone) - doesn't solvate nucleophile, keeps it strong

basics.back: Rate = k[RX] - Unimolecular, same as SN1

1) Leaving group departs → carbocation
2) Base removes β-hydrogen → alkene

Heat + base = E1 favored
Good nucleophile = SN1 favored
Zaitsev's rule - more substituted (stable) alkene forms
One-step: Base removes H while leaving group departs - concerted
Anti-periplanar - H and leaving group must be 180° apart
Rate = k[Base][RX] - Bimolecular

Strong base = Zaitsev (more substituted)
Bulky base = Hofmann (less substituted)

concepts.back:
π-participation (C=C, benzene)
n-participation (O, N, S lone pairs)
Check within 2-3 atoms from leaving group for π-bonds or lone pairs
Proper orbital overlap between participating group and leaving group

examples.back: Benzene ring participates - gives 10⁶-10¹⁴× boost in SN1

basics.back: 3° > 2° > 1° > methyl > vinyl > phenyl
Maximum hyperconjugation - 9 α-H donate electron density
Resonance > Hyperconjugation > Inductive effect
Very stable - resonance delocalizes positive charge over 3 carbons
Priority by atomic number → lowest priority away → clockwise=R, counter=S

Enantiomers: non-superimposable mirror images
Diastereomers: stereoisomers that aren't enantiomers
Has chiral centers BUT achiral due to internal plane of symmetry
Ability to rotate plane-polarized light - only chiral molecules
